top_comment.text:
*PROOF EVOLUTION IS STUPID*

Charles Darwin said:

*"If my theory [evolution],  be true  numberless intermediate varieties 
must assuredly have existed."*               
 "The Origin of Species." page 211

160 YEARS LATTER , Dr Patterson, Senior Paleontologist of the British 
Museum in London said:

*"I fully agree with your comments on the lack of evolutionary TRANSITIONS 
in my book. If I knew of any , fossil or living , I would have certainly 
included them in my book.   I will lay it on the line - THERE IS NOT ONE 
SUCH FOSSIL THAT HAS YET BEEN DISCOVERED..."*

Dr C. Patterson, Senior Paleontologist, quoted in "Darwins Enigma",  page 
89.

AND AGAIN

*"The absence of fossil evidence for intermediary stages has been a 
persistent and nagging problem for evolution."*

Dr Stephen Gould , "Evolution Now", Page 140
Professor at Harvard University in Boston

*OUCH ATHEISTS !   
HOWS IT FEEL TO SEE YOUR RELIGION COME APART ??*﻿

top_comment.text:
so. much. inaccurate. information. brain. not. able. to. handle. it...

rebooting brain

...
1) Human isn't a species, it's a genus. it's the common name of the genus 
'homo'. homo Erectus, and homo neanderthal were not 'subspecies', they were 
their own species that eventually interbred with other species of human. 
Also, that flat faced 'sub species' you mentioned, is not 'unnamed'. They 
are called homo Denisovan. Also, there were over a dozen human species have 
been identified. i have no idea where you would get the idea that there was 
only 1 or 2.

2) Megalodon was NOT the biggest predator ever, the largest predator ever 
is still alive today. guess what it's called? the sperm whale. even with 
the largest estimation of Megalodon's size, the sperm whale would still be 
around 20% larger, and at the smallest estimation of it's size, the sperm 
whale would be 2x larger then it.. Also, most archaeologist and scientist 
believe that even Basilosaurus(who you even showed a picture of) was larger 
then the Megaladon as well.﻿

comments.author: ThatGuyBen99

comments.text:
+bailey04ful  "First mutation doesn't gain anything new at all. It's not 
new information."

That's exactly what a mutation is. A change in the nucleotide sequence of a 
genome of an organism. As far as the RNA is concerned, mutated DNA is in 
fact new information which will "code" for new or changed proteins. 

"Remember the fruit fly experiment? They tried to mutate it and get it to 
evolve, it sure did mutate but guess what my comic book friends!!! It 
remained a fruit fly."

Did my previous comment just go straight over your head? I'll quote it: 
"Evolution is gradual. I don't know why this is such a hard concept to 
grasp. It takes many, many generations for substantial changes to occur." 
One single mutation is not going to make an organism into a different 
species. Thousands upon thousands of mutations from parent to offspring 
over many generations *will* do that. 

"Natural selection doesn't create anything it selects, that's it."

Why are you using this as a counter-argument? It's exactly correct. Natural 
selection is the process by which "heritable biological traits become 
either more or less common in a population as a function of the effect of 
inherited traits on the differential reproductive success of organisms 
interacting with their environment". Basically, it's the genetic version of 
process of elimination. Traits that are detrimental will become less 
common, because those organisms will have a disadvantage, die off, and not 
be able to pass on those traits. Traits that are beneficial will become 
*more* common, because those organisms will have an advantage over the rest 
and will have more chance of passing those traits on, because they survived.

"Reproduction? Really?" 

Yes, really. How are heritable traits supposed to be passed on to offspring 
if organisms don't reproduce? 

"So how did the natural selection know it needed male and female to 
survive? It's a blind process but how that happened?"

Natural selection needs reproduction to continue to work, because by 
definition that's how it works.
comments.author: ThatGuyBen99

beneficial) to do  the same for millions and millions of years, it is 
possible that it could become something closer to a dolphin . It is always 
the idea that evolution is instantaneous with you people. You don't seem to 
understand that this takes place over MILLIONS of years only after 
successful generation after successful generation breeds, implying the 
inherent need for a particular trait to survive.

For instance, if your dog on its own discovered that it could live easily 
off the plants in its habitat; (unfortunately this removes you from the 
equation because external influence can really muck it all up) that dog, in 
theory could mate to produce offspring that were to be taught to eat 
plants, like their parents. If this continues for hundreds of generations, 
due to their being a concrete reason why being carnivorous is not 
beneficial to the species you now have a situation where the dogs with the 
trait that determined that they were better off being carnivores have died 
off (say due to a lack of prey). Once the carnivorous dogs have finally 
died of, this new plant-eating breed will continue to prosper and produce 
youth that are herbivores and thus over time those dogs would develop blunt 
teeth and different digestive make ups.

Basically a species evolves when a trait that is BENEFICIAL is discovered 
by a member of the species that allows that species to thrive and 
reproduce. That member is more likely to reproduce and its genes are passed 
on ensuring that the offspring will follow suit until this goes on for 
hundreds of generations and it slowly becomes a trait that all of the 
species is born with.
comments.author: Randy “Macho Man” Savage

captions.text:
• From fossils of distant human sub-species,
to trees that survived the apocalypse which

nearly wiped out life on Earth, we count 15
fascinating pieces of history carved into

rocks and bones from the past
15 - Zombie Ant Fossil

• 2010, the 48 million year old fossil of
a leaf is discovered, one with several ants

inexplicably biting down on the surface as
they've died

• Investigations revealed a fungus had taken
control of the ants minds when they were still

alive and forced their bodies to leave the
hive to seek out a leaf

• Then, the fungus forced them to go into
a "death grip" on the leaf surface, thereby

allowing the fungus to propagate itself using
the undead ant as a host

• Creepy stuff, glad evolution decided NOT
to let this one become the norm

14 - Giant Ant
• Speaking of ants, four palaeontologists

discovered a fossil in 2011 that clearly showed
a 50 million year old winged queen ant the

size of a hummingbird from the Western Hemisphere
• It's believed this ant sprayed formic

acid as a form of self defence, and may have
followed a carnivorous lifestyle butchering

larger animals as food for the swarm
• Since it's appeared across continents,

some call it the first reported cross-Arctic
thermophilic insect resettlement

13 - Four Winged Dinosaur
• 2002, a remarkable discovery hailed as

the possible missing link between ground dinosaurs
and birds - they're also known as the "microraptor"

• This fossil estimated at around 130 million
years of age was discovered in a Chinese rock

quarry known to be a massive trove of ancient
fossils

• It used feathers on its various legs as
well as its wings to keep itself afloat

12 - Devil Frog
• This one was discovered in Madagascar,

a 70 million year old frog fossil the size
of a beach ball

• This humungous frog weighed around 4.5
kilograms with a height exceeding 41 centimeters

- to put it into perspective, the current
largest frog alive can only reach 32 centimeters

maximum
• The first fossil fragments were found

in 1993, but it took 14 years before scientists
had enough data to publicise their findings

11 - Kosmoceratops
• This one comes in from the late Cretaceous

period, just before the dinosaurs got wiped
• The fossil was discovered in Utah, what

was once known as the island continent of
Laramidia, and here we find a Triceratops-like

dinosaur with an absurd amount of horns
• Not only does it have around 5 along its

face, but it has a long head brimming with
downward spiking horns like a hair-do all

down the skull to make a total of 15
• It's generally thought to be a sexual

trait appealing to those of the opposite gender
10 - Saber-Toothed Squirrel

• 2002, a skull is found buried in rock
near northern Argentina, but since palaeontologists

can't crack open the rock to inspect it, the
skull gets shelved

• Then, 2005, a technician finally removes
the rock around the fossil and discovers a

squirrel creature with a narrow snout and
long fangs, used for hunting insects

• These things were only 20 centimetres
long, but it could still bite right through

a human neck
9 - First Ever Squid

• We find this fossilised mollusk from 500
million years ago, known as the first ever

squid and ancestor to the modern octopus
• This was discovered in the Burgess Shale

of Canada, a relic from the Cambrian period
of long ago

• This thing could shoot jets of water through
its funnel like a nozzle would, and it's BECAUSE

of this we can link them to modern day sea
creatures

8 - Whale Land Descendants
• 2007, India, a fossil is discovered of

a dog-like creature from 48 million years
ago with many of the same body structures

as aquatic animals, like bone structure, teeth,
etc

• Likewise, in 2008, it's discovered that
an ancient whale used legs to swim like a

doggy paddle, and that eventually over millions
of years these legs devolved into fins

• It turns out, whales evolved from land
mammals and we finally had the missing link

7 - Baby Dinosaur Nest
• 2011, Mongolia, the fossilised remains

of 15 juvenile protoceratops dinosaurs are
discovered by David Fastovsky

• It was the very first indication that
this particular genus remained in their nest

for a period of time, possibly protected by
a single mother

• But on the grander scope, it also revealed
that young dinosaurs were kept in the nest

during early development, cared for by the
parents

6 - Living Fossil Tree
• Not much survived the extinction event

that marked the end of the dinosaurs, but
mammals rose to dominance and certain plants

struggled though
• One tree, known as the ginkgo tree, not

only survived the extinction event, but global
warming too - in fact, you can still find

it today in harsh areas of the world, used
for medicine

• Since the trees leaves didn't absorb carbon-dioxide,
it plowed through one of the deadlist eras

on Earth, and today it's more-or-less fully
resistant to weather, disease and types of

insect
5 - Spider Attack

• During the same dinosaur period, we find
the first ever photograph of a spider attacking

its prey captured in a hundred million year
old amber fossil

• It was discovered in 2012 by experts from
Oregon State University, and they remarked,

"The wasp was watching the spider just as
it was about to be attacked, when tree resin

flowed over and captured both of them."
• Both the spider and wasp seen in the fossil

are now regarded as extinct
4 - Mysterious Human Ancestor

• A humanoid skull is discovered 40 years
ago in Kenya, but a name is never put to this

off-shoot of humanity living at the time of
homo sapiens and neanderthals

• In the years between 2 million and 1.7
million BC, it co-existed with other humanoid

species in the Rift Valleys of Africa
• While it had the big brain indicative

of the genus Homo, it also had a long, flat
face no other species had at the time, often

thought a third sub-species offshoot
• Today, theories go out there might have

been MANY sub-species at the time, not just
one or two

3 - Ghost Dragon
• Northeast China, some palaeontologists

discover a wildly snaggle-toothed skull belonging
to a mysterious 120 million year old flying

reptile
• Its proper name is Guidraco venator, Chinese

or Latin for 'ghost dragon hunter', a variety
of pterosaur with a wingspan extending beyond

10 feet in diameter
• Though these aren't technically dinosaurs,

they're the worlds first flying vertebrates
and this particular fossil was found a good

distance away from the place we currently
assumed they'd call home - still a mystery

2 - Giant Penguins
• New Zealand penguins, alive 25 million

years ago, ones that stood nearly 4 feet 6
inches tall

• At the time of their existence, most of
New Zealand was underwater leaving isolated,

rocky land masses that kept these giant penguins
safe from predators and provided a plentiful

food supply
• These specific fossils from 1977 were

reconstructed using two separate bones and
parts and pieces from a King Penguin - and

is now known as the largest of the five species
that lived on New Zealand

1 - Largest Shark Jaw
• This comes from the biggest predator ever

to exist on Earth: the Megalodon
• This thing died out 1.5 million years

ago, weighing in at over 100 tons of pure
carnage, and it took 20 years to reconstruct

this jaw from fragments
• The jaw set is composed of over 180 individual
teeth, MASSIVE ones
